title.narrative: F.a: Alianza Biodiversidad, new challenges, new commitments

description.narrative: The project strengthens the social movement working for agricultural biodiversity in Latin America, led by local communities, indigenous peoples and peasant organisations aiming for food sovereignty. The work focuses on capacity-building of the movement in themes related to food sovereignty and agricultural biodiversity. It entails the following activities: i) production and dissemination of the Biodiversidad, sustento y culturas magazine in both Spanish and Portuguese, ii) maintenance of the Biodiversidadl a.org website, iii) production of education material to support the social movements, iv) organization of regional analysis and coordination workshops, v) organization of local level trainings, vi) organization of a distance learning course on public polic ies on agricultural biodiversity and vii) internal coordination of the Biodiversity Alliance implementing the activities. The Alliance consists of 10 civil society organisations across Latin America.The project beneficiaries include indigenous peoples and peasant social movements, rural producers, urban consumers, academic and pedagogic societies as well as media in support of the social movements. 10 000 copies are printed of each of the four editions of the Biodiversidad magazine annually, the website has 60 000 visitors monthly, the distance learning course has 40 participants, whereas the workshops have 300.Accion por la Biodiversidad is an Argentine NGO registered in 2004. It promots agricultural diversity in Latin America. AcBio maintains Biodiversidad la, a website launched in 2000, focusing on agricultural biodiversity in Latin America. The site receives approximately 1 000 daily visitors from grass root organisations, social movements, media and universities. The site?s electronic bulletin has 10 000 subscribers. Since 1994 AcBio together with ten Latin American NGOs has produced a magazine called Biodiversidad, sustento y culturas. The magazine is published four times a year both in Spanish and in Portuguese. In addition to electronic format, altogeth er 10 000 paper copies are printed in ten Latin American countries.AcBio collaborates with several national and international networks through sharing of information, providing thematic support, training and carrying out joint campaigns and activities. Its main allies include the international peasant movement Via Campesina and GRAIN, which promotes agricultural biodiversity on global level.
